instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power on problems
threads.message: Hello, got yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with problems. This one has PP3V42 at 3.41V, PPBUS is 8.59V. I am missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>. When I power it on, the current spikes to .452A then drops to 26mA. Seems to me like it is trying to power on then shutting down. I checked some power rails but these boards I get with this issue and no apparent corrosion anywhere are baffling. I have 2 of them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power on problems
threads.message:
If board tries to start <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at least; check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> too.
This board should make 2 attempts before starting.
Check if all voltages pulse, including VCORE.
Any history available?
Check for corrosion, especially at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
